fields.headline: My media
fields.bodyText: Newspapers: The Independent and the Guardian when I'm away, and the Observer. I like the commentators in them. I like Robert Fisk in the Independent, though there are one or two I don't like. I particularly dislike the Sun and the Mail. They're just vile papers, they stir up dirt, they're immoral and unprincipled. Magazines: The Radio Times and Red Pepper as regular magazines and that's about it. I have so much reading material around I have to be careful, or it stops me reading books. Books: I'm reading the last part of [Philip Pullman's] His Dark Materials trilogy. I think it's extraordinary. I'm trying to finish it so I can start reading The Corrections. TV: I'm very depressed by television, though it is my medium. I'm depressed that the government is going to relax the rules so that the channels are going to be self-governing and won't have to show any drama, so there'll be more of these programmes I dislike - these voting programmes and cookery and makeover shows. It's cheap, diluted television. I like The Office and [Alan] Partridge, Newsnight Review and David Attenborough's wildlife programmes. But I don't like programmes that demand that I have to watch the next week or the next day at the same time. Radio: I enjoy the radio. I love listening to it more and more. I like to hear people talking on the radio - Woman's Hour and Desert Island Discs. I like the concerts on Radio 3 and Radio 2 in the evenings. Adverts: Orange have got a good one out - it's nothing to do with telephones until the very end. Guinness do good adverts, and I like the beer advert with the wounded soldier and the foot on the pump. A good advert is a work of art. New Media: I really enjoy email and use the internet for tickets and hotels. But I don't browse - I don't like looking at the screen for more than half an hour. · Roger Lloyd Pack plays Trigger in Only Fools and Horses, and Owen Newitt in The Best Of The Vicar Of Dibley, out on CD and video
